verses.text: There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was blameless and upright, fearing God and turning away from evil.
verses.comment: The description of Job as blameless and upright sets the tone for the whole book, showing his close relationship with God, almost as a model for true piety rooted in reverence and moral integrity. 'Blameless' and 'upright' here do not mean sinless, but devoted and sincere—note a parallel with Noah in Genesis 6:9. Job's persistent fear of God anticipates the biblical theme of wisdom rooted in filial fear.

verses.text: And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
verses.comment: The specific mention of 'seven sons and three daughters' signals a sense of divine blessing and completeness—seven is often used for fullness in Scripture. This echoes the fruitful families of the patriarchs (Genesis 5, Genesis 46:26–27).

verses.text: He possessed seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large household. So this man was greatest of all the people of the east.
verses.comment: Wealth in livestock signified God's blessing—compare Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (Genesis 12:16, 26:13–14). Job is a near-royal figure, referencing the prosperity God gives to His faithful servants. The 'people of the east' are understood as nations east of Israel, famed for wisdom and affluence.

verses.text: His sons used to go and hold a feast in each one's house on his day, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
verses.comment: The regular family feasts demonstrate both the unity and joy of Job's household—an image of harmony. Note also their inclusivity towards their sisters; this is countercultural in the ancient Near East and implies a kind of equality and spiritual solidarity.

verses.text: When the days of feasting had run their course, Job would send for them and consecrate them; and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, 'Perhaps my children have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts.' So Job did this continually.
verses.comment: Job acts as a priest for his family, offering intercessory sacrifices. This pattern points ahead to mediatorship and atonement seen later in Israel's sacrificial system. His diligence is a sign of spiritual leadership and care for the souls entrusted to him, a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came among them.
verses.comment: 'Sons of God' likely refers to angelic beings who attend upon God’s throne (cf. Psalm 89:7, Daniel 7:10). The adversary (Satan) appears as an accuser—a role continued in Zechariah 3:1. This assembly hints at a heavenly council, showing God’s sovereignty over all powers.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Satan, 'From where do you come?' Then Satan answered the LORD, 'From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking up and down on it.'
verses.comment: God permits Satan’s presence and questions him, asserting His authority. Satan’s roaming mirrors the serpent’s cunning mobility in Genesis and hints that the earth is a battleground for testing faith (cf. 1 Peter 5:8).

verses.text: And the LORD said to Satan, 'Have you considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil?'
verses.comment: God Himself praises Job, paralleling His delight in other righteous individuals—Noah, Enoch. This highlights the possibility of intimate friendship with God through grace and persistent virtue.

verses.text: Then Satan answered the LORD and said, 'Does Job fear God for nothing?'
verses.comment: The challenge is that of disinterested love. The accusation is that Job’s piety is motivated by self-interest, not genuine devotion—raising the theme of testing faith in a way that will echo through the rest of the book.

verses.text: Have you not put a hedge around him and his house and all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
verses.comment: The hedge symbolizes God’s protective providence over the righteous (Psalm 125:2). The prosperity is explicit—a visible sign of covenant faithfulness, but the story will soon test whether faithfulness can endure without visible blessing.

verses.text: But stretch out Your hand and touch all that he has, and he will surely curse You to Your face!
verses.comment: Satan claims suffering will uncover a shallow faith—tying suffering to the authenticity of devotion. The narrative invites reflection on why the righteous are allowed to suffer, a question taken up later by Christ, the innocent sufferer.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Satan, 'Behold, all that he has is in your power; only against him do not stretch out your hand.' So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD.
verses.comment: God sets boundaries for Satan. Even in trial, God remains sovereign. This limitation foreshadows how suffering, though permitted, is never outside divine providence, as seen in Jesus' Passion (John 19:11)—only what the Father allows will occur.

verses.text: Now on the day when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
verses.comment: The feasting scene sets the context for Job’s trial, emphasizing both the unity and the vulnerability of earthly happiness.

verses.text: a messenger came to Job and said, 'The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,
verses.comment: The impending losses begin with the animals that were central to Job’s wealth. The structure builds dramatic suspense, showing the unraveling of what God had given, a call to detach from worldly possessions in pursuit of deeper faith.

verses.text: when the Sabeans attacked and took them, and struck down the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you.'
verses.comment: The Sabeans, known plunderers from the south, bring the first wave of disaster. The repeated phrase 'I alone have escaped to tell you' (vv. 15, 16, 17, 19) emphasizes the totality of Job’s losses, prefiguring later devastations—and human suffering that sometimes comes rapidly and unexpectedly.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, 'The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants and consumed them; and I alone have escaped to tell you.'
verses.comment: 'Fire of God' may refer to lightning. This rapid succession of news heightens the drama, and points to disasters both from human enemies and from nature, suggesting trials come from multiple sources, all under God's mystery.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, 'The Chaldeans formed three bands and made a raid on the camels and took them, and struck down the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you.'
verses.comment: The Chaldeans were later associated with Babylon and are here noted as marauders. The cumulative calamity suggests Job’s loss is thorough and systematic. Such experiences often prompt deeper spiritual searching for meaning and hope.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, 'Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
verses.comment: The final blow targets Job’s family, the heart of his joy, showing the extent of his suffering. The sequence from possessions to children hints a hierarchy of what is most precious.

verses.text: and behold, a great wind came from across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young people and they died; and I alone have escaped to tell you.'
verses.comment: Natural disaster, after human violence, completes Job’s tragedy. Such events call to mind the sovereignty of God over even chaos and tragedy, recalling the tempests subdued by Christ (Mark 4:37–39).

verses.text: Then Job arose, tore his robe, and shaved his head, and fell to the ground and worshiped.
verses.comment: Tearing the robe and shaving the head are traditional acts of mourning (see Genesis 37:34). Job’s response—falling in worship—reveals his faith: he seeks God first, even in adversity, modeling a humble acceptance of God’s will reminiscent of Christ at Gethsemane (Luke 22:42).

verses.text: And he said, 'Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked I shall return there. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.'
verses.comment: Job’s response is a profound act of faith—in total loss, he still blesses God. This reflects a willingness to accept trials from God’s hand, developing the biblical teaching that suffering can be redemptive and meaningful. The phrase 'blessed be the name of the LORD' echoes throughout liturgy and worship, becoming a formula for praise amid suffering.

verses.text: In all this Job did not sin or charge God with wrongdoing.
verses.comment: Despite all calamity, Job’s response is faithful and submissive. He does not accuse God, pointing to the highest virtue in enduring unjust suffering. This anticipates the silent suffering of the righteous throughout Scripture, especially fulfilled in Christ (Isaiah 53:7; 1 Peter 2:23). His heroic endurance is a foundation for later spiritual teaching on perseverance and trust in God—even when His ways seem mysterious.
